How to find a remote job in 30 days. My life as a (wannabe) digital nomad

I recently quit my job to follow my dream of being location independent. I read thousands of posts about digital nomad life and, of course, it seemed amazing: full of extreme sports, paradise beaches, colorful cocktails and multicultural friends. It could be like that, but before hiking mountains, surfing on the ocean and getting lost in the jungle with monkeys, you need to have a remote job, which is what fancy articles usually don’t tell you. And this is what I’m going to do in the next 30 days: I’m going to look for a job.

Since it’s a short period of time, I need a plan. Feel free to add your own points based on your experience, they will be more than welcome!

Let everybody know that you’re are looking for a job

In the last 3 years I never sent a curriculum vitae, but I was called for an interview by at least 15 different companies and I accepted two of these jobs. I just let my contacts and friends know that I was looking for a radical change in my life. I’ll do the same thing this time (I’m writing this post both to spread the voice and receive some suggestions and tips). Facebook friends are not just the ones that like your vacation photos, they could be a great professional opportunity.

Be ready on LinkedIn

I recently changed my LinkedIn profile based on what are my future career expectations. For instance, I’d like to foster companies’ growth through marketing and business development, so I wrote some of my past measurable achievements regarding user acquisition, sales increase and partnership relations. I also started asking to some of my ex colleagues to leave me a review. Of course, if you have any feedback on my LinkedIn profile, don’t hesitate to tell me, I will be glad to modify it again! :)

Track everything

Looking for a job is a job itself, so I know exactly how much time I spend for each task (thanks Toggl for making my life easier) and I can organize my days using Podio to remember what I have to do. For example, I have a list of people I should ping on something and I wrote for each of them the important points of our previous conversations.

I created also a spreadsheet to know when I applied to what and the status of the application (no response, email-refused, email-accepted, call, interview, negotiation). Moreover I use bit.ly to track every link in my cv and on my application forms, just to be sure they read it or not.

Improve your skills

Well, changing a career requires also a professional and personal improvement. So it’s better to use the time wisely. You can choose one or more of the free or paid courses on Udemy, Coursera or 99u. For instance, I decided to take some courses on digital marketing and growth hacking, I joined some online communities and newsletters about growth hacking and I signed up on Fluentify and Italki to improve my business language skills.

Create profile on the right platforms

I will dedicate an entire day to create my profile on some recruitment platforms: Angel.co for remote startup jobs, Escape The City for social enterprise jobs, Landing.Jobs because they recently added a remote jobs section and Jobbatical because they have several job positions located in Malta, where I currently am.

Go running or do sport

Attitude is fundamental to look for a job. I used to get a bit nervous when I wasn’t exercising for a while. So, since you start looking for a job, you’ll probably have more free time, then take advantage out of it! For example, I’m totally not a morning person (I also wrote a post about why you should not be a morning person), but since I don’t have to wake up at 6 to go running before going to work, I started running at 8.30/9 and it changed quite a bit my morning routine training for a 5k race. Bonus point: I can run near the seaside. :)

If you have tips and suggestions, please don’t hesitate to leave a comment or a private note.

If you want to contact me for any reason, you can write an email at a.anniballo@gmail.com.
